results.abstract: Skylab, 1st US space station, is blasted into earth orbit by Saturn 5 rocket from Cape Kennedy at 1:30 PM on May 14, but deployment failure of its solar panels, which convert sunlight into electricity, forces 5-day delay and serious curtailment of manned operations aboard massive research spaceship; flight controllers rept post-launching examination of radioed data discloses that an 'anomaly' occured within space station 63 secs after lift-off, when rocket was 40,000 ft from ground and undergoing its greatest stresses and vibrations; say data indicate that space station also lost its aluminum meteoroid shield early in flight and that it is having difficulty stabilizing itself in orbit 271 mi above earth; mission officials reptdly have ruled out possibility that astronauts will be able to correct any of malfunctioning systems after they arrive at space station and express pessimism that problems may be overcome through new automatic radio commands from earth; project dir W C Schneider says it is 'too early' to determine how long 2d and 3d planned crews will be able to occupy space station; mission planners express hope that manned functions of space station can be extended by drawing extra electricity from Apollo command ship; functions of solar panels discussed; launching described; illus of Saturn rocket with Skylab space station leaving launching pad at Cape Kennedy and of project dir Schneider and Skylab astronauts; schematic diagram of Saturn rocket with Skylab space station; of space station with deployed solar panels; of solar panel wing assembly

results.abstract: ed, commenting on problems besetting Skylab space station, maintains 'a price is being paid for the effort to stage Skylab on a shoestring,' noting that NASA, as result of budget cuts, constructed space station 'out of existing bits and pieces of available equipment and eschewed much of the painstaking and expensive testing and retesting that contributed so largely to the brilliant record of accomplishment and safety scored by the Apollo program'; sees problems hinting at great difficulties and substantial expense involved in creation of 'even a small space station, let alone the large manned space laboratories many scientists are looking forward to'; urges coupling of programs by US and USSR into 'a truly internatl effort' which would benefit everyone

headline.main: Skylab in Trouble

results.lead_paragraph: Unexpected technical mishaps are, regrettably, not exactly a novelty in the space program. It is still not so long, ago that the explosion aboard the moon-bound Apollo 13 imperiled the lives of its three astronaut passengers and forced abandonment of their lunar-landing plans in order to return the men safely to earth.

headline.main: Pilot in Search of New Frontier; Paul Joseph Weitz

results.snippet: Comdr. Paul Joseph Weitz, like Comdr. Joseph P. Kerwin a space rookie, most closely matches the stereotyped image of the astronaut: blond, blue-eyed, conventional, unemotional. And taciturn.
results.lead_paragraph: Comdr. Paul Joseph Weitz, like Comdr. Joseph P. Kerwin a space rookie, most closely matches the stereotyped image of the astronaut: blond, blue-eyed, conventional, unemotional. And taciturn.

results.abstract: 3 US astronauts on May 26 are launched from Cape Kennedy for orbital rendezvous with malfunctioning Skylab space station; fail to dislodge jammed solar power wing and, after 9 attempts, finally succeed in docking with Skylab; transmit TV pictures of malfunctioning vehicle; link-up is achieved after 3 hrs, during which crew effects changes in wiring of Skylab's docking hatch; achieves 'hard dock' by using jumper cable to bypass series of control switches and route power directly to motor that operates docking latches; Comdr Weitz fails to dislodge solar power wing using 10-ft-long shepherd's crook and pruning shears; radioes: 'I hate to say it, but we ain't going to do it with the tools we got'; Capt Conrad says wing appears to be 'hooked in there like its nailed in'; repts: 'Solar wing 2 was gone, completely off the bird. Wing 1 is partially deployed, a bulge of meteoroid shield holding it'; repts also that gold foil covering much of Skylab's hull, exposed because of missing thermal shield, has turned considerably black in sun; temperatures within space station have remained excessive as result of loss of thermal micrometeoroid shield during launching from Cape Kennedy and because of failure of solar power wing; crew will transfer from Apollo spacecraft to Skylab wearing face masks in event that laboratory contains noxous gases from deterioration of overheated plastic materials; hope to deploy mylar awning over space station through airlock in side of vehicle; launching of astronauts from Cape Kennedy described; scientists illus at Kennedy Space Center; Saturn 1B illus leaving launching pad; TV picture of Skylab as seen from Apollo spacecraft

headline.main: Space With a Purpose; OBSERVER

results.snippet: Every 93 minutes three men pass in the sky overhead on a route that takes them around the planet. Round and round they go, day and night. It is an astounding thing for men to be doing, but we are so inured to the daily occurrence of the astounds ing...

byline.original: By Russell Baker

results.lead_paragraph: Every 93 minutes three men pass in the sky overhead on a route that takes them around the planet. Round and round they go, day and night. It is an astounding thing for men to be doing, but we are so inured to the daily occurrence of the astounds ing that we scarcely pause anymore to reflect how remarkable it is.

results.abstract: Skylab astronauts, in TV news conf on May 28, rept that their orbiting space station is in 'excellent shape' and that they fully expect to complete planned 28-day mission despite high onboard temperatures and limited electricity; conduct 1st med tests by taking and processing blood samples and checking condition of their hearts and circulatory systems; Dr Kerwin notes, contrary to expectations, that it is possible to sense difference between 'up' and 'down' in zero-gravity environment, observing that all it takes is a 'conversation' with the brain; concludes that it must therefore be possible for eyes and brain to override body's vestibular system, which is centered in inner ear and provides sense of balance; astronauts are saving fecal and urine samples for return to earth; rept special scale for weighing waste materials is not functioning properly; Comdr Weitz conducts experiment in pressure chamber to test effect of pooling of blood in legs, and pedals stationary egrometer to determine his capacity for strenuous work in zero-gravity environment; temperatures inside space station continue to fall slowly, reaching 86 degrees Fahrenheit; flight controllers estimate atmospheric temperature in Skylab will stabilize at 75 degrees Fahrenheit

results.snippet: Mikhail D. Millionshchikov, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the principal spokesman for scientific contacts with the West, died here yesterday at the age of 60.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Mikhail D. Millionshchikov, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the principal spokesman for scientific contacts with the West, died here yesterday at the age of 60.

results.abstract: use of solar telescope by Skylab astronauts seen marking emergence of a new era in astronomy, one in which observations are made from above earth's atmosphere with manned instruments that are comparable in sophistication with those used on earth; scientists are optimistic that telescopes and other scanners aboard Skylab will be able to solve number of solar mysteries such as recently discovered 'interplanetary blast,' which apparently originates in lower atmosphere of sun and propagates out into solar system at speeds that reach 700 mi-per-sec; blasts have been rarely seen since 1st observations 18 mos ago, but presumably are related to more common solar flares; scientists hope observations may disclose process that causes flares; cluster of instruments aboard Skylab that are aimed at sun consists of 6 primary telescopes and spectroscopes, plus several smaller aiming telescopes; array, with 4 windmill-like panels to generate power from sunlight, is operated by 3 massive gyroscopes containing 142-pound flywheel rotating at 9,100 revolutions per minute; through telescopes astronauts can see sun in red light emitted by hot hydrogen; solar physicists hope telescope experiments will provide detailed information on solar activity; particular interest centers on observing interplanetary blast with telescopes aboard Skylab and unmanned Orbiting Solar Observatories that were launched mos ago; schematic diagram of Skylab's X-ray Event Analyzer-Telescope

headline.main: Skylab Solar Sightings Open Era in Astronomy.; Orientation of Craft Observation Plans Path of Plasma Clouds

results.snippet: Today's activation of the Skylab solar telescopes marks the emergence of a new era in astronomy--one in which observations are made from above the atmosphere with manned instruments comparable in sophistication with those used on earth.

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVANSpecial to The New York Timesz

results.lead_paragraph: Today's activation of the Skylab solar telescopes marks the emergence of a new era in astronomy--one in which observations are made from above the atmosphere with manned instruments comparable in sophistication with those used on earth.

results.abstract: Planned US Skylab 1 research projects include inventory of land use in terms of forests and various agr crops in Equador and Philippines

headline.main: Skylab Targets: Locusts, Trees, Craters; Sensors Checked Survey of Volcanoes

results.snippet: A plague of locusts in the Sudan, an infestation of trees at the mouth of the Rio Grande and a chain of restless Central American volcanoes are typical targets of the Skylab earth-scanning that began today.

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVANSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A plague of locusts in the Sudan, an infestation of trees at the mouth of the Rio Grande and a chain of restless Central American volcanoes are typical targets of the Skylab earth-scanning that began today.

results.abstract: US Skylab 1 astronauts begin on May 30 to survey earth by aerial photography in order to expand man's understanding of his mineral resources, crops and forests, pollution and weather

headline.main: Skylab Crewmen Begin Earth Survey Experiment; Good Health Reported Batteries Shut Down Cooling Off Slowly

results.snippet: From an orbit 270 miles ,high over the western part of the United States, the Skylab 1 astronauts began today a survey of the earth that should expand man's understanding of his mineral resources, crops and forests, pollution and weather.

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: From an orbit 270 miles ,high over the western part of the United States, the Skylab 1 astronauts began today a survey of the earth that should expand man's understanding of his mineral resources, crops and forests, pollution and weather.
